page.title: 17Local History.
page.content: The house in Poulter Park was built in Edwardian times. It was built by the Poulter family and they lived in it through two world wars. The park was established in 1911 and in 1928 the estate of twenty acres was bought as a public open space by the London and Greater London Playing Field Association. The trustees of Reginald Clifford Puolter gave Â£5000 towards the purchase. The Carshalton Urban District Council has undertaken to maintain it as a public open space for ever. Woodcote House at Wrythe Green is thought to have been the former Rosehill Toll house.It is constructed from wooden boarding which is laid in a herring-bone pattern.It had a fine weather vane on the roof,dated 1745, which has been presented to the Victorian and Albert Museum.
